No, you don‚Äôt. You can easily develop you own code to support in-app purchases, particularly now that
provides SwiftUI views and view modifiers to enable user purchases. Prior to the introduction of
, things were more complicated and there were three areas of particular difficulty:

pattern is used throughout the API

However, even if you develop your own in-app purchase code there are still a few areas of complexity, particularly with regard to subscriptions. You‚Äôll probably end up creating something very similar to
The best way to get familiar with
is to create a simple, but full-featured (from an in-app purchase perspective) demo app. You may be surprised how little code is required to implement in-app purchases:
In this guide we‚Äôll be developing a demo app (

) for an on-line florist that sells a range of flowers and other related services like home visits to water and care for house plants. We‚Äôll develop the app for both macOS and iOS, using a single multi-platform Xcode project.
Before getting started you‚Äôll need to download
To get started, create a new
Once Xcode has created the project select¬†
In the search field enter the URL of the¬†

We now need to add the necessary in-app purchase capabilities to our project. Select your project‚Äôs target and navigate to the¬†
Before we do anything else we need to define the products we‚Äôll be selling. Ultimately, this will need to be done in¬†
. However, Xcode provides us with a local, on-device way of experimenting with in-app purchases.

, introduced in Xcode 12, is a test environment allows you to do early testing of in-app purchases in the simulator, without having to set anything up in App Store Connect. You define your products locally in a¬†
file. Furthermore, you can view and delete transactions, issue refunds, cancel subscriptions, and a whole lot more. There‚Äôs also a new¬†
¬†framework that enables you to do automated testing of IAPs.
Each product that we will sell in our app is identified by a unique
. You can either hard-code these ids into your app, or store them in an easily-modifiable property list file. In our demo app we‚Äôll use the property list approach.
When our demo app runs it will need to get¬†
¬†product information. This includes things like a product‚Äôs name and description in the appropriate local language, and prices in the local currency. When an app has been released, or when using
(more on this later) this information comes from the App Store. When using local Xcode StoreKit testing the information comes from the StoreKit Configuration file.
The switch between local StoreKit testing and the App Store is transparent in terms of our in-app purchase code: it‚Äôs a simple configuration change.

Also note that we‚Äôve adopted a
This isn‚Äôt strictly necessary, so product ids like ‚Äúlarge-flowers‚Äù and ‚Äúgold‚Äù are also perfectly acceptable as product ids only need to be unique within each particular app.
At this point we need to discuss product
This type of product represents something that can be purchased and then ‚Äúused up‚Äù in some way. The user can purchase multiples of this type of product.

For example, a consumable product might be an ‚Äúsuper-powers token‚Äù that grants the user extra abilities, for a limited time, in a game. In our demo we offer a consumable that represents an on-site visit to water and care for your plants. The product lasts for one visit and then expires. The user may purchase as many visits as they want.

A non-consumable product is something the user purchases once and which lasts ‚Äúforever‚Äù. An example would be purchasing access to ‚Äúpro-level‚Äù functionality in a camera app. In our demo we sell non-consumable products like flowers and chocolates.

An auto-renewable subscription represents a service that requires a regular payment. For example, a specialist skiing weather app might require a monthly subscription. The user may cancel the subscription at any time, in which case access to the service will end when the next renewal payment becomes due.
Note that subscriptions are offered as part of a
of subscription products. For example, in the demo app we define a ‚ÄúVIP‚Äù subscription group (see Products.plist above) which contains two product
: ‚Äúgold‚Äù (the highest value) and ‚Äúsilver‚Äù. The position of the product id in the file determines the

. Products that appear towards the top of the file are of higher value than those defined towards the bottom of the file. We‚Äôll see later how easy it is to support users upgrading, downgrading or cancelling subscriptions.
üëâ Note that SKHelper does not support the older type of
-renewable subscription, the use of which is discouraged by Apple.
We can now create the StoreKit configuration file that will be used to provide localized product data during initial development and testing.
From Xcode 14 onwards you can choose to create a¬†
¬†configuration file that is linked to in-app purchases already defined in App Store Connect. Once you‚Äôve created the synced¬†
¬†configuration file you can‚Äôt edit it locally in Xcode, all changes have to be made in App Store Connect.

In production your app will request localized price (and other) information from the App Store.

content.text: Why do we have two product lists?!

inlineContent.text: At this point you may very reasonably be wondering why we have a
file. Couldn‚Äôt we just make do with one, because data (product ids) is duplicated in the two files?
There is a fundamental principle in software development that may be summarized by the

ourself. Essentially, if you find you‚Äôve duplicated code or data you should generally find a way of abstracting it into a single entity, and then referencing that entity as required from multiple places. Experience shows that if you‚Äôve got basically the same thing scattered throughout your project, if you need to modify it there‚Äôs a good chance you‚Äôll forgot to update
the occurrences. This can lead to difficult-to-find bugs and misery!
So, because we‚Äôve defined our products in the StoreKit configuration file, it seems obvious that we should use
as the repository for our product id data. Retrieving configuration data at runtime from the
configuration file is intended for use¬†
a good idea to use it for production too. This is why the

file is not included in any of your targets by default. It would be all too easy to allow ‚Äútest products‚Äù to somehow make it into the release build! So, in this case it‚Äôs better to violate the DRY principle, rather than risk something far worse!
Before moving on to other topics, we‚Äôll need to
StoreKit testing in Xcode, as it‚Äôs disabled by default.

If you now build and run the app you should see a list of all the products we configured earlier:
Each product has a short text description, an image clipped to a circular shape and a price button
The list of products is sorted into groups by product type, with non-consumables shown first, then consumables, with subscriptions shown at the end of the list
Tapping on the price button starts the standard purchase process for the product
There is a ‚ÄúRestore Missing Purchases‚Äù button, as required by the App Store
Tapping on the product‚Äôs image shows a sheet containing product details:
When you run the app you‚Äôll see that prices are in US dollars. This is because, by default in the StoreKit test environment, the App Store¬†
. To support testing other locales you can change this.

. If you change the localization settings you‚Äôll need to make sure to add text matching that locale (e.g. French) to each product in the

content.text: Customizing the appearance of the product list

inlineContent.text: As you can see, you get so much functionality for just two lines of code! However, there are many ways in which you can customize how
behaves. For example, we can modify the display of product details like this:

code: // When the user taps on the product's image SKHelperStoreView passes
// its `ProductId` to this closure, which we can use to customize
Text("Here is some text about why you might want to buy this product.")
Text("We think you'll find this product very useful!")

inlineContent.text: In a production app you would need to use the¬†

¬†parameter passed to the closure to provide different details for each product. For example, you might create a string catalog which provides product details text. The key for each string in the catalog could be the¬†
There are two main ways of purchasing products:
Uses the standard purchase button UI and purchase flow provided by StoreKit
You provide your own purchase button and UI
Here‚Äôs the code required for the easy-to-use option - it‚Äôs exactly as we used earlier for displaying the list of products:

code: // SKHelperStoreView() lists all available products for this app.
// Purchasing is supported. Purchased products will be grayed-out.
// Tapping on a product's image shows details for that product.

inlineContent.text: If you want more feedback on purchases you can add the optional

code: case .cancelled: print("Purchase of \(productId) was cancelled by the user")
case .revoked:   print("Access to the product \(productId) was revoked by the App Store")
case .upgraded:  print("Product \(productId) was upgraed to a higher value product by the App Store")
case .pending:   print("The purchase of \(productId) is pending awaiting parental approval")

content.text: How do I know if a product has been purchased

inlineContent.text: A common scenario is to make the display of content dependent on a purchase. The following sample code shows how you can easily check the status of a purchase

code: /// This `SmallFlowersView` demonstrates how to check if the user has access to a
/// purchase-dependent resource. In this case, access to the "small flowers" resource
/// is only granted if the user has purchased the "com.rarcher.nonconsumable.flowers.small"
/// 1. Check the purchase before the View appears using:
/// 2. If the user hasn't purchased the product we display a link to `SKHelperStoreView` and
///    pass the product id of the small flowers product. This causes `SKHelperStoreView` to display
///    only information about the small flowers product, rather than all available products
Text("You've purchased the small flowers - here they are, enjoy!").padding()
Text("You haven't purchased the small flowers and don't have access.").padding()
Text("Here is some text about why you might want to buy this product.")

inlineContent.text: If you don‚Äôt want to make use of
you can create your own purchase button and other purchase-related UI.
A simple example is shown below.
The steps required are as follows:
for the product you want to purchase
, along with localized product information and a cached value for the user‚Äôs entitlement to use the product.
The easiest way to get the required product is to create an
view modifier, which allows you to be notified when localized product information
has been successfully retrieved from the App Store (SKHelper does this automatically when it‚Äôs initialized).
method and await for the result. If
then the purchase was a success.

code: // Display a button using the localized price
let result = await store.purchase(product.product)  // Start the purchase flow for the product
// This view modifier is called when localized product information becomes available or updated
product = products.first { product in product.id == ContentView.productId }  // Get the small flowers product

inlineContent.text: When purchases are made an important part of StoreKit‚Äôs workflow is automatic
of the transaction. The validation process ensures that the user is entitled
to use the product on that particular device. This involves examining the encrypted purchase receipt, which is issued by the App Store whenever a purchase is made or restored.
Prior to the introduction of StoreKit validation of receipts was a tricky business. The developer had four validation options:
talking to Apple‚Äôs receipt validation server),
Happily, we no longer have to deal with the details of this as StoreKit will validate transactions for us. To see how this works let‚Äôs review what happens when the user

code: await store.purchaseCompletion(for: product, with: try? result.get())
// This view modifier is called when localized product information becomes available

inlineContent.text: Notice how we make use of StoreKit‚Äôs
method to handle the display of purchase-related UI and process the actual payment. We then use StoreKit‚Äôs
modifier to be notified about the completion of the purchase process and call our
method essentially has three jobs: check the result of StoreKit‚Äôs automatic validation, log the result and then
(if any) to inform them of the result of the purchase. The app can then decide whether or not to make the

code: internal func purchaseCompletion(for product: Product, with result: Product.PurchaseResult?) async -> (transaction: Transaction?, purchaseState: SKHelperPurchaseState) {
await validatedTransaction.finish()  // Tell the App Store we delivered the purchased content to the user
// Let the caller know the purchase succeeded and that the user should be given access to the product

inlineContent.text: We go through a similar validation process when we check if the user has purchased a product using SKHelper‚Äôs
In this case we use StoreKit‚Äôs
to get the user‚Äôs entitlements for the particular product and then check
the automatic validation result. Here‚Äôs a simplified snippet:

code: public func isPurchased(productId: ProductId) async -> Bool {
if !latestTransaction { return false }  // No transaction means the user has not purchased the product
// Check the validation result to see if it's verified

inlineContent.text: Apples‚Äôs documentation states that apps must provide a mechanism to allow users to manually restore previous in-app purchases.
Failure to provide a ‚ÄúRestore‚Äù button will result in apps being rejected during the App Store review process.
Apple states that manually (and programmatically) restoring previous purchases should no longer normally be necessary. However, you MUST still provide a manual
restore feature (see below) or your app will be rejected during the review process.
Programmatically restoring purchases simply requires an async call to
. However, it‚Äôs not a good idea to initiate a restore unless the user
specifically requests it. This is because the user will immediately be prompted to authenticate with the App Store. This behaviour can be very disconcerting
for the user, as it may not be obvious why they‚Äôre being asked for their credentials.
option to display a button that will restore
is rendered it will display a ‚ÄúRestore Missing Purchases‚Äù button at the bottom of the available/purchased products list.
The App Store supports the concept of ‚Äúask-to-buy‚Äù purchases, where parents can configure an Apple ID to require their permission to make purchases.
When a user makes this type of purchase the
method will have a value of
This state can also be applicable when a user is required to make banking changes before a purchase is confirmed.
With StoreKit testing we can easily simulate pending purchases to see if our app correctly supports them. To enable ask-to-buy support in StoreKit select
the .storekit configuration file and then select
